Justification: To assess for the presence of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the calf.
To evaluate for the presence of a blood clot; elevated levels may indicate clot formation.
To check for signs of infection or other underlying conditions that may contribute to the symptoms.
To provide a more detailed view of the veins in the leg if DVT is suspected but not confirmed by ultrasound.
To assess for peripheral artery disease, which could also cause calf pain.
